section.title: MXPSQL_MPARC_iter_t

para.para: Ptr type of the iterator, should be initialized to null on first use.

section.para: This should be initialized to NULL to prevent problems with uninitialized value.
Don't ever try to dereference this thing.
This can never be declared as a non pointer object.

section.title: MXPSQL_MPARC_t

para.para: Ptr type of the archive, should be initialized to null on first use.

section.para: This should be initialized to NULL to prevent problems with uninitialized value.
Don't ever try to dereference this thing.
This can never be declared as a non pointer object.
Not atomic or thread safe (never aim to be that for C99 suport and portability, you do it yourself with platform threads (pthreads, winapi threads or C11 threads if you can)).

section.title: MXPSQL_MPARC_uint_repr_t

para.para: Typedef our uint representation to make it easy to refactor.

section.para: This is currently typedef'd to uint_fast64_t, but we can switch to unsigned long long or size_t

para.para: Error states, these are self explanatory. But I give them brief anyways.

entry.para: Invalid value or generic but more specific errors than MPARC_IDK.
The archive you provided is actually not an archive determined by the 25 character long MAGIC NUMBER or some other factor, but most likely the magic number.
The format version of the archive is too new to be digested.
CRC checksum check and comparison failed.
FILE* seems to be having problems as ferror reports true or just that something is wrong with the archive itself.

section.title: MPARC_basename()

para.para: Get the basename of the file paht.

section.para:
Parameters
filename
file path
Returns
char* Base name of filename
On unix, it is strrchr'd on '/' only.
On windows, it is not only strrchr'd on '/', it is also strchrr'd on '\' (How you say the \ character on C)

para.para: My calloc, for easy plug and switch. Extensions should use this instead of calloc.

entry.para: size of array (if applicable, else put 1)

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: void* allocated memory pointer

note.title: Note
note.para:
MPARC_calloc has its pitfalls. Don't fall for it.
Right now is using C's calloc, so it is at the mercy of that function as calloc has flaws.
Allocating a zero sized object with MPARC_calloc, danger is from that it is implementation defined.

para.para: Wipe everything (I mean every single file) off the archive.

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: MXPSQL_MPARC_err the status code if successfully done

para.para: Construct the archive into a file.

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: MXPSQL_MPARC_err the status code if successfully done

para.para: Construct the archive into a file stream.

entry.para: the file stream, should be opened in "rb" mode

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: MXPSQL_MPARC_err the status code if successfully done

note.title: Note
note.para: fpstream should be closed and opened manually

section.title: MPARC_construct_str()

para.para: Construct the archive into a string.

section.para:
Parameters
structure
the target structure
output
the storage string
Returns
MXPSQL_MPARC_err the status code if successfully done
Note
manually free output string with 'MPARC_free', not 'free' or 'delete' for forward compatibility.
Construct the archive into a string.
SEE THIS TO SEE THE FILE FORMAT OF THE ARCHIVE THIS PART IS IMPORTANT TO SEE HOW IT IS IMPLEMENTED AND THE FORMAT
How is the file constructed (along with little parsing information to make your own parser):

listitem.para:
Build the header: Format: MXPSQL's Portable Archive;[VERSION]${JSON_WHATEV_METADATA}>[NEWLINE]
The ';' character separates the Magic numbers (very long with 25 character I think) from the version number and json metadata
The '$' character separates the version and magic numbers from the metadata
The '>' character works to indicate the start of entries The newline is an anomaly though, but just put it in there
JSON_WHATEV_METADATA can be implementation defined This C implementation will ignore any extra metadata
Construction note: Make sure to base64 your metadata entries to prevent issues with parsing.
Parsing tips: Split ';' from the whole archive to get the magic number first Then split '>' from to get the special info header The split '$' from the special info header to get the version and extra metadata

Build the entries Format: [CRC32_OF_JSON]%{"filename":[FILENAME],"blob":[BASE64_BINARY], "crcsum":[CRC32_OF_blob]}[NEWLINE]
The '%' character is to separate the checksum of the JSON from the JSON itself
You can add other metadata like date of creation, but there must be the entries "filename", "blob" and "crcsum" in the JSON This C implementation will ignore any extra metadata.
"filename" should contain the filename. (don't do any effects and magic on this field called "filename") "blob" should contain the base64 of the binary or text file. (base64 to make it a text file and not binary) "crcsum" should contain the CRC32 checksum of the content of "blob" after converting it back to it's original form. ("blob" but wihtout base64)
Repeat this as required (how many entries are there you repeat)
Construction note: The anomaly mention aboved is because the newline is added before the main content
Parsing note: When parsing the entries, split from the begin '>' marker first, and then the end '@' marker. Then split each by newlines. Ignore if a line start with '#' (EXACTLY WITH THAT CHARACTER, there must not even be any whitespace before it), a comment marker. Also ignore if a line is empty. Then, foreach split '%' to get the crc and json. Then compare the JSON to the crc. Then parse the JSON as usual.
You could parse extra info in your implementation, but this C Based implementation will ignore extra ones. I repeat this line again.

Build the footer Format: @~
the '@' character is to signify end of entry the '~' character is to signify end of file
Parsing note: Make sure to not have anything beyond the footer, not even a newline.

section.para: Final note: This file should not have binary characters.

Follow this (with placeholder) and you get this: MXPSQL's Portable Archive;[VERSION]${JSON_WHATEV_METADATA}>[NEWLINE][CRC32_OF_JSON]%{"filename":[FILENAME],"blob":[BASE64_BINARY], "crcsum":[CRC32_OF_blob]}[NEWLINE]@~

A real single entried one: MXPSQL's Portable Archive;1${"WhatsThis": "MPARC Logo lmao-Hahahaha"}> 134131812%{"filename":"./LICENSE.MIT","blob":"","crcsum":"15584406"}@~

the target structure

you want to overwrite? set to a non zero value. No overwrite? then set to 0

the source file to duplicate from.

the destination file
Returns
MXPSQL_MPARC_err Yes.
Internally implemented with MPARC_push_ufilestr and MPARC_peek_file

para.para: Simple version of MPARC_extract_advance.

entry.para: NULL if there is no directory to make, not NULL if it needs you to make a directory

section.title: MPARC_extract_advance()

para.computeroutput: MXPSQL_MPARC_err MPARC_extract_advance (MXPSQL_MPARC_t * structure, char * destdir, char ** dir2make, void(*)(const char *) on_item, int(*)(char *) mk_dir)

para.para: Advanced extraction function.

section.para:
Parameters
structure
the target structure
destdir
the destination directory
dir2make
NULL if there is no directory to make, not NULL if it needs you to make a directory
on_item
invoked everytime a new item is iterated over
mk_dir
invoked when directory is needed to be created, return 0 on success, non-zero on error. Overrides dir2make.
Returns
MXPSQL_MPARC_err error status, some code are special, see details
if the error code returns MPARC_OPPART, check dir2make to see if it needs you to make a new directory

para.para: Print the error message of your stream of choice.

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: int Level of error

section.title: MPARC_free()

para.para: My free, for easy plug and switch. Extensions should use this instead of free.

section.para:
Parameters
mem
memory to free
Note
MPARC_free has its pitfalls. Don't fall for it.
Right now is using C's free, so it is at the mercy of that function as free has flaws.
Common one:
Double free, danger is that it is undefined behaviour to do so.
Free not allocated memory, danger is that it is also undefined behaviour to do so.
Not freeing memory if you are done with it, danger is that you played yourself with memory leaks.

para.para: Utility function that free the list that you created with MPARC_list_array.

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: MXPSQL_MPARC_err successful?

section.title: MPARC_list_foreach()

para.computeroutput: MXPSQL_MPARC_err MPARC_list_foreach (MXPSQL_MPARC_t * structure, int * cb_aborted, MXPSQL_MPARC_err(*)(MXPSQL_MPARC_t *, const char *) callback)

para.para: Foreach, with call backs.

section.para:
Parameters
structure
the target structure
cb_aborted
a flag that indicated if an error code resulted from abortion request or an internal error. Can be NULL.
callback
callback function that gets called on every iteration
Returns
MXPSQL_MPARC_err the status code if successfully done. MPARC_OK if successfull, other error codes if aborted (dependent on callback).
For the callback function:
To continue an iteration, return MPARC_OK.
To abort the loop, return any other values in MXPSQL_MPARC_err other than MPARC_OK. cb_aborted is set to 1 and the value is returned from callback.
Other details:
If an internal error occurs, the error code corresponding to the error is returned, but cb_aborted is set to 0.

para.computeroutput: MXPSQL_MPARC_err MPARC_push_ufilestr (MXPSQL_MPARC_t * structure, char * filename, unsigned char * ustringc, MXPSQL_MPARC_uint_repr_t sizy)

para.computeroutput: MXPSQL_MPARC_err MPARC_push_ufilestr_advance (MXPSQL_MPARC_t * structure, char * filename, int stripdir, int overwrite, unsigned char * ustringc, MXPSQL_MPARC_uint_repr_t sizy)

para.para: Push an unsigned string as a file.

entry.para: strip the directory from the filename, set to 0 to disable
if set to anything other than a 0, overwrites the entry if it exists. if set to 0, prevents you from overwriting it if it exists. set to 0 to disable ability to overwrite (already explained)

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: MXPSQL_MPARC_err the status code if successfully done

note.title: Note
note.para: Filename only works on forward slash if stripdir is set due to basename only supporting that operation.

para.computeroutput: MXPSQL_MPARC_err MPARC_push_voidfile (MXPSQL_MPARC_t * structure, char * filename, void * buffer_guffer, MXPSQL_MPARC_uint_repr_t sizy)

formalpara.title: Returns

section.title: MPARC_query()

para.computeroutput: MXPSQL_MPARC_err MPARC_query (MXPSQL_MPARC_t * structure, char *** output, char * command, ...)

para.para: Query the structre for files that match a specific criteria.

section.para:
Parameters
structure
the target structure
output
The files that match a specific criteria.
command
The criteria to look for
...
Vaargs that depend on the command arg
Returns
MXPSQL_MPARC_err Success or a failure (MPARC_SUCCESS if yes, MPARC_KNOEXIST if the command is invalid, MPARC_IVAL if a problem occured)
There are multiple commands available in this query function. This list is formated as the following: [command] - [description] - [required vaargs] Available commands (case sensitive): size_bigger - List all files that is bigger than the specified size - [number, preferably MXPSQL_MPARC_uint_repr_t, a 1 is equal to a single byte (2 means two bytes, 3 means three bytes, etc...)] size_equal - List all files that is equal to the specified size - [number, preferably MXPSQL_MPARC_uint_repr_t, a 1 is equal to a single byte (2 means two bytes, 3 means three bytes, etc...)] size_smaller - List all files that is small than the specified size - [number, preferably MXPSQL_MPARC_uint_repr_t, a 1 is equal to a single byte (2 means two bytes, 3 means three bytes, etc...)] extension - Get the file extension based from the first dot - [a string of the file extension, do not include the first dot in the parameter] rextension - Get the file extension based from the last dot - [a string of the file extension, do not include the first dot in the parameter]

The output parameter is always terminated with NULL. It itself and its content is also dynamically allocated, so you must deallocate it manually using 'MPARC_free', not 'free' and 'delete[]' for forward compatibility.

Passing the wrong vaargs will lead to undefined behavior, I cannot defend you from against that unless you cooperate with me. C Standard Library says so to do undefined behaviour in vaargs implementation.

para.computeroutput: MXPSQL_MPARC_err MPARC_query_vlist (MXPSQL_MPARC_t * structure, char *** output, char * command, va_list vlist)

para.para: A version of MPARC_query that accepts a va_list instead.

entry.para: The files that match a specific criteria
A list that is suppoused to be a vaargs that depend on the command arg

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: MXPSQL_MPARC_err Success or a failure (MPARC_SUCCESS if yes, MPARC_KNOEXIST if the command is invalid, MPARC_IVAL if a problem occured)

note.title: Note
note.para: You are responsible for starting and ending vlist. Also look at MPARC_query for more bad things that could happen.

section.title: MPARC_readdir()

para.computeroutput: MXPSQL_MPARC_err MPARC_readdir (MXPSQL_MPARC_t * structure, char * srcdir, int recursive, int(*)(char *, int, char **) listdir)

para.para: Read a directory into the structure.

section.para:
Parameters
structure
the target structure
srcdir
the source directory to read from
recursive
read from subdirectories if not set to 0
listdir
function to list a directory, shall not be NULL or else it returns an error. This is the function that handles listing the file and recursion.
Returns
MXPSQL_MPARC_err error status of reading
listdir Prototyping the first parameter of the listdir function is the current directory that should be read from
the second parameter indicates if it should be recursive, set to 0 if not, don't if not
the third parameter is what files it has found, should be an array of string, terminated with NULL and Calloc'ed or Malloc'ed (pls Calloc it) as it relies on finding NULL and the array getting freed
the return value should always be 0 for success, other values indicate failure

section.title: MPARC_realloc()

para.para: My realloc, for easy plug and switch. Extensions should use this instead of realloc.

section.para:
Parameters
oldmem
old memory to change size
newsize
new size
Returns
void* reallocated memory pointer
Note
MPARC_realloc has its pitfalls. Don't fall for it.
Right now is using C's realloc, so it is at the mercy of that function as realloc has flaws.
Common one:
In place realloc, danger is from when it errors out and now you created a memory leak.
Reusing old realloc pointers, danger is that it may have been invalidated.
Allocating a zero sized object with MPARC_realloc, danger is that it used to be implementation defined before C23, after C23 is now undefined behaviour.

section.title: MPARC_rename_file()

para.computeroutput: MXPSQL_MPARC_err MPARC_rename_file (MXPSQL_MPARC_t * structure, int overwrite, char * oldname, char * newname)

para.para: Rename an entry.

section.para:
Parameters
structure
the target structure
overwrite
you want to overwrite? set to a non zero value. No overwrite? then set to 0
oldname
the file you want to change name
newname
the new name
Returns
MXPSQL_MPARC_err the sttaus code if successfully done. MPARC_KNOEXIST if oldname is not there and more...
Internally implemented with MPARC_push_ufilestr, MPARC_pop_file and MPARC_peek_file

para.computeroutput: int MPARC_sfperror (MXPSQL_MPARC_err err, FILE * filepstream, char * emsg)

para.para: Print the error message to your stream of choice with a message of your choice.

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: int Level of error

para.para: Copy string with no length limits.

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: char* duplicated string

note.title: Note
note.para: Use 'MPARC_free' to deallocate instead of 'free' and 'delete' for forward compatibility.

para.para: Get error string from MXPSQL_MPARC_err.

entry.para: output error string, can be NULL if an error occured

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: int Level of error

para.computeroutput: char * MPARC_strndup (const char * src, size_t ilen)

para.para: Copy string with length limits.

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: char* duplicated string

note.title: Note
note.para: Use 'MPARC_free' to deallocate instead of 'free' and 'delete' for forward compatibility.

para.computeroutput: size_t MPARC_strnlen (const char * str, size_t maxlen)

para.para: My strlen for portability.

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: size_t actual str length or maxlen

para.computeroutput: char * MPARC_strtok_r (char * s, const char * delim, char ** save_ptr)

para.para: Strtok Safe Edition.

entry.para: string to be tokenized, must be mutable
delimiter to be used while tokenizing
storage space for the rest of the 'she' string

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: char* The token

section.title: MPARC_swap_file()

para.computeroutput: MXPSQL_MPARC_err MPARC_swap_file (MXPSQL_MPARC_t * structure, char * file1, char * file2)

para.para: Swap 2 entries.

section.para:
Parameters
structure
the target structure.
file1
the filename to swap with file2.
file2
the filename to swap with file1.
Returns
MXPSQL_MPARC_err Lazy.
Internally implemnted with MPARC_push_ufilestr and MPARC_peek_file
